prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
The winner of a Xiangqi, or Chinese chess, tournament has been stripped of his title after allegations of inappropriate behaviour.

Yan Chenglong has also been accused of cheating by using a communication device analogous to anal beads.

The 48-year-old has been stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

However, the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) says it's impossible to prove accusations of cheating.

Xiangqi has been hugely popular across Asia for hundreds of years.

According to the CXA, Mr Yan started drinking with friends in his hotel room shortly after winning the title of "Xiangqi King" at a national tournament held on the Chinese island of Hainan last week.

He then defecated in the hotel bath in an act "that damaged hotel property and violated public order and good morals", said the CXA statement.

The CXA was forced to address rumours circulating online that Mr Yan had cheated using anal beads equipped with wireless transmitters to send and receive signals.

"Based on our understanding of the situation, it is currently impossible to prove that Yan engaged in cheating via 'anal beads' as speculated on social media," the CXA said.

As punishment for bad behaviour, Mr Yan was stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

The association did not disclose the amount of prize money Yan was forfeiting, but Xiangqi tournaments often promise winners tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars), according to AFP.
stories:
A Xiangqi, or Chinese chess, champion has lost his title following claims of unacceptable conduct. The individual, Yan Chenglong, is being investigated for allegedly using a device akin to anal beads to cheat.

Yan, aged 48, was dethroned and prohibited from competing for a year due to his misconduct. However, the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) expressed difficulty in proving cheating allegations.

The ancient game of Xiangqi has long been cherished throughout Asia.

Following his victory at a national tournament on Hainan Island last week, Yan reportedly consumed alcohol with friends in his hotel room. Subsequently, he was accused of damaging hotel property and violating public morals by defecating in the bathtub.

Rumors emerged online accusing Yan of cheating through the use of anal beads containing wireless transmitters. The CXA stated that, at present, they cannot verify this claim.

As a consequence of his unsavory behavior, Yan surrendered his title and was barred from participating in competitions for a year. The CXA did not disclose the forfeited prize money, but Xiangqi tournaments typically award winners significant sums, estimated to be in the thousands of dollars by AFP.

A Chinese chess, or Xiangqi, titleholder, Yan Chenglong, has had his championship revoked due to allegations of inappropriate behavior. Yan, 48, faces an investigation over accusations of employing a questionable device resembling anal beads to gain an unfair advantage.

Following his triumph at a recent national Xiangqi tournament on Hainan Island, Yan was reportedly seen consuming alcohol with companions in his hotel room. He was later accused of vandalizing hotel property and disregarding public decency by defecating in the bathtub.

Unsubstantiated online rumors have suggested that Yan resorted to cheating through the utilization of anal beads equipped with wireless transmitters. The Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) has yet to provide confirmation of this assertion.

As a result of his distasteful actions, Yan relinquished his title and was suspended from participating in competitions for a year. The CXA has remained tight-lipped about the forfeited prize money, although Xiangqi tournaments are known to bestow substantial rewards upon winners, valued in the thousands of dollars according to AFP.

Despite Yan being implicated for employing dubious gadgets, which purportedly contain the capacity to transmit wires, during the game, no definitive proof has been uncovered. The Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) has yet to comment on the issue.

Consequently, Yan has been deprived of his accolade and barred from participating in upcoming competitions for a year due to his contentious behavior. The CXA has not yet disclosed their plans for the forfeited reward money, despite data from AFP suggesting generous prizes are standard in Xiangqi tournaments.
